results.snippet: The Presidential Medal of Freedom, which was presented to Philip C. Habib today by President Reagan, is the highest civilian award given by the United States.   The honor, which was first conferred in 1963 by President John F.  Kennedy, is...

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The Presidential Medal of Freedom, which was presented to Philip C. Habib today by President Reagan, is the highest civilian award given by the United States. The honor, which was first conferred in 1963 by President John F. Kennedy, is conferred by Presidents on people who have made ''exceptionally meritorious contributions to the security or national interest of the United States, to world peace or to cultural or other significant public or private endeavors,'' according to the White House.

results.snippet: HOORAY FOR YIDDISH! By Leo Rosten.  363 pages. Simon & Schuster. $15.95.   LOOK who's talking! It's that Yiddish maven, Leo Rosten, who should know from what he's writing. Now he gives us ''Hooray for Yiddish!'' not quite the same as his ''The Joys...
results.lead_paragraph: HOORAY FOR YIDDISH! By Leo Rosten. 363 pages. Simon & Schuster. $15.95. LOOK who's talking! It's that Yiddish maven, Leo Rosten, who should know from what he's writing. Now he gives us ''Hooray for Yiddish!'' not quite the same as his ''The Joys of Yiddish,'' but again with the definitions and jokes and insights that made so many readers plotz merrily the last time around. You enjoyed last time? So you should enjoy this time. What's not to enjoy? If you are expecting, maybe, a Ruskin-type critique here, boy, have you got the wrong number.

headline.kicker: TEXAS ROCKET BUILT ON 'SHOESTRING' CARRIES FREE ENTERPRISE

results.snippet: A private corporation with only seven permanent employees launched a spacecraft made out of surplus rocket parts from a cattle ranch here today, ushering in what its promoters believe will be a new era of commercial exploitation of space...

byline.original: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: A private corporation with only seven permanent employees launched a spacecraft made out of surplus rocket parts from a cattle ranch here today, ushering in what its promoters believe will be a new era of commercial exploitation of space technology. The gleaming white craft, carrying a mock payload of 40 gallons of water, lifted off dramatically with a roar and a puff of white smoke at 10:17 A.M. It sketched a high parabola over the choppy waters of the Gulf of Mexico and splashed down 321 miles from this barren island 10 1/2 minutes later. The successful test flight of the 36-foot rocket, symbolically named Conestoga 1 after the covered wagons used by American pioneers, was a pivotal event for its owner, Space Services Inc. of America. The Houston-based concern had persuaded 57 investors to chip in $6 million on the argument that the time had come for private enterprise to get a piece of the action in space, which has long been dominated by governments. Plan to Launch Satellite The company's chairman, David Hannah Jr., a Texas real estate developer and space enthusiast, said the company was now prepared to push ahead with plans for the first privately launched satellite in 1984. Space Services hopes to sell ''low-cost, market-oriented'' space services that are tailored specifically to meet the needs of oil companies and other potential customers needing satellite tracking and communication.

headline.main: DISREGARD OF RISKS AND SKEPTICS PAID OFF

results.snippet: A reporter once asked Toddie Lee Wynne, an 85-year-old oil executive from Dallas who was a backer of Space Services Inc. of America, whether trying to launch spaceships commercially was too great a business risk. According to a Space Services...
results.lead_paragraph: A reporter once asked Toddie Lee Wynne, an 85-year-old oil executive from Dallas who was a backer of Space Services Inc. of America, whether trying to launch spaceships commercially was too great a business risk. According to a Space Services official who was there, Mr. Wynne simply pointed to one of his oil rigs and said, ''It's a lot less risky than that business over there.'' With such disregard for the risks and the skeptics, Space Services, a Houston company backed largely by Texas businessmen, took a giant step yesterday toward convincing the world that a private company might one day compete with the National Aeronatics and Space Administration in launching satellites into space. From a ranch in Texas, it successfully launched a spaceship made of surplus rocket parts.

headline.main: PRIMARIES WON BY EX-GOVERNOR, TWO INCUMBENTS

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT

results.snippet: A former Massachusetts Governor trying a comeback and two important members of Congress won key tests yesterday as 12 states and the District of Columbia held primary elections.   But another incumbent, Senator Howard W. Cannon of Nevada, was...
results.lead_paragraph: A former Massachusetts Governor trying a comeback and two important members of Congress won key tests yesterday as 12 states and the District of Columbia held primary elections. But another incumbent, Senator Howard W. Cannon of Nevada, was locked in a tight race with Representative James D. Santini as he sought the Democratic nomination for a fifth term. In Massachusetts, former Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, attacking his successor's administration as corrupt and too supportive of President Reagan, defeated the incumbent, Gov. Edward J. King, for the Democratic nomination for Governor, just as Mr. King did four years ago when Mr. Dukakis was the incumbent. In the heavily Democratic Bay State, Mr. Dukakis will be favored over the Republican nominee in November, John W. Sears, a former Boston City Councilor.

headline.main: EXHIBITION TRACES ROLE OF BLACKS IN AVIATION

results.snippet: The history of blacks in aviation, not documented in most history books, includes a bit of the romance of early aerial combat and a great deal of the struggle over segregation.   A new exhibit at the National Air and Space Museum, ''Black Wings:...

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The history of blacks in aviation, not documented in most history books, includes a bit of the romance of early aerial combat and a great deal of the struggle over segregation. A new exhibit at the National Air and Space Museum, ''Black Wings: The American Black in Aviation,'' traces the involvement of blacks in aviation from Eugene Bullard's service in France in World War I to the four black astronauts assigned to the space shuttle program. Lieut. Col. Guion S. Bluford Jr. will be the first black astronaut in space on the eighth shuttle flight, tentatively scheduled for next year. The exhibit, made up mainly of pictures and mementos, is the first that the museum has devoted to blacks and depicts an era about which little is known. Trained in France The exhibition describes how the first licensed black American pilots had to go to France to receive their training. Eugene Bullard, for instance, failed in his effort to break the racial barrier in aviation in this country and joined the Foreign Legion in 1914, according to historical accounts. He went on to become a pilot with the Lafayette Escadrille in World War I and received 15 medals, including the French Legion of Honor.

headline.main: NOBELISTS SAY U.S. AID WAS VITAL TO WORK

results.snippet: A poll of American Nobel Prize winners in science, conducted by Senator John Glenn, indicates that Federal financial support was vital to the work of the majority of them.   The poll, described by the Ohio Democrat's staff as the only available...
results.lead_paragraph: A poll of American Nobel Prize winners in science, conducted by Senator John Glenn, indicates that Federal financial support was vital to the work of the majority of them. The poll, described by the Ohio Democrat's staff as the only available source of information on the subject, reached 48 of the 54 Americans who won a Nobel Prize in physics, chemistry or medicine between 1967 and 1981. It found that 29 of them had received more than 90 percent of their research support from the Federal Government, and that another 11 had got more than half of their support from Federal agencies.

results.snippet: By Anatole Broyard SPACE. By James A. Michener. 622 pages.  Random House. $17.95.   THOUGH, as a poet said, ''Panoramas are not what they used to be,'' we can still find them in the novels of James Michener. What he lacks in style, he makes up in...
results.lead_paragraph: By Anatole Broyard SPACE. By James A. Michener. 622 pages. Random House. $17.95. THOUGH, as a poet said, ''Panoramas are not what they used to be,'' we can still find them in the novels of James Michener. What he lacks in style, he makes up in scope. His books are almost encyclopedic in size and he usually puts an encyclopedic amount of information in them.

results.snippet: Jack L. Swigert Jr., the former astronaut, said today that he was being treated for cancer in his bone marrow, but he would continue his campaign for election to Congress. Mr. Swigert, the Republican nominee in the Sixth Congressional District,...
results.lead_paragraph: Jack L. Swigert Jr., the former astronaut, said today that he was being treated for cancer in his bone marrow, but he would continue his campaign for election to Congress. Mr. Swigert, the Republican nominee in the Sixth Congressional District, said he was continuing the campaign because of ''the optimism expressed by my doctors in the ability to control the cancer.'' The former astronaut underwent surgery several months ago for another malignancy, a tumor in his nasal passage.
